metadata.synopsis: Perverse conditions within a British reform school reach a boiling point.

reviews: It's a film that hammers home the depravity of institutionalization...
Alan Clarke's direction is hard, clear and utterly uncompromising, and the performances of his largely unfamiliar cast are so authentic and convincing as to make one flinch.
The visual equivalent of spare, brilliant prose that occasionally bleeds (and bleeds and bleeds) into poetry.
Scum lives up to its title to this day, its manic energy balanced with an assured and naked openness that creates a searing level of realism and, as such, savagery.
One of the great films about boys and violence ...
Clarke's prison, like Losey's, crystallizes the societal rot on the outside
Has a raw power that is disturbing.
